articles.title: WA news LIVE: WA family heartbroken after dog stabbed to death at park
articles.summary: WA family heartbroken after dog stabbed to death at park. Israel expects to receive all living hostages from Gaza in a single group to be transferred by Hamas on Monday. Opposition leader Sussan Ley's performance rating has crashed in the latest Resolve Political Monitor. Global marine heatwaves will help fuel a wetter than average summer in Australia.

articles.title: WA news LIVE: WA family heartbroken after dog stabbed to death at park
articles.summary: WA family heartbroken after dog stabbed to death at park. Israel expects to receive all living hostages from Gaza in a single group to be transferred by Hamas on Monday. Opposition leader Sussan Ley's performance rating has crashed in the latest Resolve Political Monitor. Global marine heatwaves will help fuel a wetter than average summer in Australia.

articles.title: Glaciers losing their cooling edge: Global study warns of faster melting by mid-century
articles.author: Gaurav Talwar
articles.summary: By the 2040s, most of the world's mountain glaciers will "recouple" with the warming atmosphere, accelerating melt rates and amplifying the impacts of climate change. In South Asia, glaciers on the humid southern slopes of the Himalayas currently show stronger temperature decoupling, maintaining surface air temperatures roughly 2°C cooler than the surrounding atmosphere.

articles.title: The World's First Climate Tipping Point Has Been Crossed, Scientists Say
articles.summary: The second 'Global Tipping Points' report published by the University of Exeter found that warm-water coral reefs are passing their tipping point. The planet is predicted to cross the 1.5°C threshold within the next 5 years. A September report also found that the global temperature threshold required to trigger the widespread dieback of the Amazon rain forest is lower than previously thought.

articles.title: World Hits First Climate Tipping Point, Ushering in a New Reality
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: The Global Tipping Points Report 2025 shows that the planet is already experiencing its first critical Earth system tipping point. Global warming has already reached 1.4°C above pre-industrial levels. Coral reefs' thermal tipping point is between 1.0 and 1.5°C of global warming, with a central value near 1.2°C. The Amazon rainforest's temperature threshold for widespread dieback is lower than previously understood. The COP30 summit in Brazil represents a critical forum for embedding tipping points within climate negotiations.

articles.title: Climate tipping points are being crossed, scientists warn ahead of COP30
articles.author: Alison Withers
articles.summary: Coral reefs are in an irreversible die-off due to climate change. The last two years were Earth's warmest on record. The world is on track for about 3.1 degrees C of warming in this century. Renewables accounted for more electricity generation than coal this year for the first time.

articles.title: Sheep flock declines before a rebuild
articles.author: McPherson Media Group
articles.summary: The nation's sheep flock is declining. Producers are preparing for gradual rebuild, according to Meat & Livestock Australia. The sheep population is declining as producers prepare for a gradual rebuild. The decline is due to fewer sheep being born in the last few years.

articles.title: Coral reefs are first environmental system to pass climate "tipping point"
articles.author: Emily Mae Czachor
articles.summary: Coral reefs are the first environmental system on Earth to pass a climate "tipping point" according to a new report. The report was released by the Global Systems Institute in England. It comes a month before COP30, an annual climate change conference in Belém, Brazil.

articles.title: Coral reefs become first environmental system on Earth to pass climate "tipping point," report says
articles.author: Emily Mae  Czachor
articles.summary: Coral reefs are the first environmental system on Earth to pass a climate "tipping point" according to a new report by climate scientists. Global Tipping Points report examines some of the fundamental processes that support life on this planet in terms of their proximity to benchmarks that may signal permanent damage.

articles.title: 'Tipping point' threshold reached for world's coral reefs, report suggests
articles.author: Peter de Kruijff
articles.summary: The first "tipping point" for the Earth has been reached, according to an international report from 160 scientists in 23 countries. Global warming has caused mass dieback of the world's warm water coral reefs. The report identified 25 vulnerable Earth systems that could "tip". This means they might abruptly change to a different state and that change is irreversible within a human lifetime.

articles.title: 'A tragedy': World may have reached first climate 'tipping point' as coral reefs face collapse
articles.summary: Coral reefs are on the brink of collapse worldwide due to rising sea temperatures caused by climate change. The world may have reached the first of many feared 'tipping points' in the Earth's ecosystems, with warm-water coral reefs now on the verge of collapse.

articles.title: Key climate tipping point is BREACHED for the first time – and scientists warn it will cause ‘catastrophic harm' unless urgent action is taken
articles.author: WILIAM HUNTER
articles.summary: A key climate tipping point has been irreversibly breached for the first time, according to a new report. Warm-water coral reefs are now passing their thermal tipping point, which means they will almost certainly be lost. Global warming is on track to climb past 1.5°C (2.7°F) and scientists warn that Earth will continue to cause 'catastrophic harm' unless urgent action is taken.

articles.title: The World's First Climate Tipping Point Has Been Crossed
articles.author: Simmone Shah
articles.summary: The Earth has passed its first climate tipping point, according to the second 'Global Tipping Points' report published today by the University of Exeter. The report also found that the global temperature threshold required to trigger the widespread dieback of the Amazon rain forest is lower than previously thought.

articles.title: First climate tipping point reached after coral reef diebacks, scientists warn
articles.author: Rebecca Speare-Cole
articles.summary: The world has reached its first climate tipping point as global warming causes widespread diebacks of warm-water coral reefs. The Amazon rainforest could pass its tipping point before the world hits 2C warming. The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) faces collapse sooner than previously thought. The AMOC's collapse would plunge north-western Europe into an ice age.

articles.title: Corals are disappearing, pushing Earth to its first major ‘tipping point'
articles.author: Grist
articles.summary: There is a tipping point where the Earth system abruptly and dramatically changes, often irreversibly, like the Amazon rainforest turning into a savanna. The tipping point is a point of no return that is already perilously close to the Earth's surface.

articles.title: Coral collapse signals Earth's first climate tipping point
articles.author: Carolyn Gramling
articles.summary: Rising heat in the oceans has pushed corals around the world past their limit, causing an unprecedented die-off of global reefs and threatening the livelihoods of nearly a billion people, according to a new report published October 13. Earth has officially passed its first climate tipping point.

articles.title: Coral reefs, ice sheets and Amazon rainforest approaching a tipping point due to global heating, report says
articles.author: Graham Readfearn
articles.summary: The Global Tipping Points report claims the planet has reached its first catastrophic tipping point linked to greenhouse gas emissions. Coral reefs have been in the midst of a global bleaching event since January 2023, with more than 80% of them affected by extreme ocean temperatures. Global heating is now at about 1.4C. The upper threshold of 1.5C would be hit in the next 10 years.

articles.title: Planet's first catastrophic climate tipping point reached, report says, with coral reefs facing ‘widespread dieback'
articles.author: Graham Readfearn Environment
articles.summary: The world has reached its first catastrophic tipping point linked to greenhouse gas emissions, according to a new report. Coral reefs are home to a quarter of all marine species and are one of the most vulnerable systems to global heating. Global heating is now at about 1.4C. Without rapid and unlikely cuts to greenhouse gases, the upper threshold would be hit in the next 10 years.

articles.title: World's coral reefs crossing survival limit
articles.author: RTÉ News
articles.summary: The world's tropical coral reefs have almost certainly crossed a point of no return as oceans warm beyond a level most can survive. It is the first time scientists have declared that Earth has likely reached a so-called "tipping point" - a shift that could trigger massive and permanent changes in the natural world.

articles.title: Where's the rain Atlantic Canada?
articles.author: The Weather Network
articles.summary: Persistent dry conditions are putting a strain on Atlantic provinces. Dylan Kikuta reports on the weather conditions with Meteorologist Dylan  Kikuta on "Today's Weather with Dylan" at 10:30 a.m. ET.   Â. Â

articles.title: Climate change devastates Lahaul-Spiti apple growers
articles.author: Dipender Manta
articles.summary: Lahaul and Spiti has seen unseasonal heavy snowfall in the first week of October. The snowfall came at a critical time when the apple crop was ready for harvesting. Orchards in the Lahaul valley have suffered severe losses and many farmers have reported up to 80 per cent crop damage. The recent snowfall has dealt a blow to the local economy.

articles.title: Climate justice, migration, and resilience — inside the AF2025 summit.
articles.author: NZ Herald
articles.summary: Professor Steven Ratuva joins Ryan Bridge on Herald NOW as the UN's largest climate event - Adaptation Futures - kicks off in Christchurch. The event is taking place in the city of Christchurch and is led by UN's Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon.

articles.title: DCS announces Remote Learning Day for Hatteras students on Monday, Oct. 13
articles.author: Submitted Story
articles.summary: DCS announces Remote Learning Day for Hatteras students on Monday, Oct. 13 due to continued hazardous road conditions, strong winds, and ocean overwash. Tomorrow will be a regular school day for schools located North of Oregon Inlet. Additional updates will be provided if conditions deteriorate.

articles.title: Pro-Palestine protests across Australia
articles.summary: Thousands of people have taken to the streets across Australia to express their support for the Palestinian people and scepticism about the recently brokered ceasefire deal's longevity. What we know so far is that they are sceptical about the deal's long-term sustainability.

articles.title: ‘The blob', rain and La Nina: What the summer forecast holds for Australia
articles.author: Bianca Hall
articles.summary: The Bureau of Meteorology has warned of a higher risk of severe weather between October and April. A negative phase of the Indian Ocean Dipole is under way, associated with increased rainfall in southern and eastern Australia during spring. A weak La Nina is predicted for later this spring, but forecasters predict conditions will return to neutral in summer. 'The blob', a large marine heatwave, is spanning much of the North Pacific Ocean, bringing predictions of heavy rain and slow-moving storms to North America.

articles.title: ‘The blob', rain and La Nina: What the summer forecast holds for Australia
articles.author: Bianca Hall
articles.summary: Global marine heatwaves will fuel a wetter than average summer in Australia. A heatwave in the Pacific nicknamed 'the blob' threatens to cause intense winter storms in the United States. The Bureau of Meteorology has warned of a higher risk of severe weather between October and April.

articles.title: Climate disasters cost India $12 billion in 2025: Why ecology is key to economic growth
articles.author: Raj S Joshi
articles.summary: India's economic growth is being defined by the growing frequency and intensity of climate-related disasters. Natural catastrophes cost India over $12 billion in 2025. India's current disaster management budget and insurance coverage are inadequate for the scale of the risk. India must mobilise dedicated climate and ecosystem restoration funds to fund watershed development, afforestation, resilient urban infrastructure and flood-proof housing.

articles.title: Roger Cook warns Canberra that 32 per cent cut to skilled migration will make housing crisis worse, not better
articles.summary: Roger Cook warns Canberra that 32 per cent cut to skilled migration will make housing crisis worse, not better. The West Australian has exclusive information from Roger Cook. The article can be read here: http://www.thewestanews.com.au/news/features/special-interest-reports/2013/01/30/40/40.html#storylink=cpy.

articles.title: ‘It's come to a complete stop': Why you'll be waiting a while to see Circular Quay upgraded
articles.author: Sydney Morning Herald
articles.summary: The long-promised revamp of the wharves is at a standstill despite concerns raised over the years about their age and the need for a revamp. It is not clear when the revamp will take place. It's not clear if it will ever happen at all.

articles.title: Avoid beaches and erosion hotspots, Cape Hatteras National Seashore says
articles.author: WITN Web Team
articles.summary: Cape Hatteras National Seashore advises the public to avoid area beaches and erosion hotspots due to flooding caused by ocean overwash and water seeping through dune structures. Highway 12 on Ocracoke is closed from Pony Pen to the north. Off-road vehicle routes will be impassable for much of today and during high tides over the next several days. The beach in front of the Village of Buxton is closed due to hazardous conditions.

articles.title: Here's why the numbers don't add up on our shark net strategy
articles.author: Letters to the Editor
articles.summary: There are 84 shark attacks since 1937. 1300 people die each year on the roads in NSW. 150 coastal drownings in the 2023/24 year could have been prevented if lifesavers were available. The government's immigration policy allows for 185,000 permanent visas between 2025 and 2026.

articles.title: UK spearheads polar climate change research as US draws back
articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.summary: The RRS Sir David Attenborough is heading to Antarctica next week to help advance climate change-linked science projects. Western nations are spearheading studies there while the United States withdraws. US President Donald Trump has pulled out of the Paris climate accord and gutted science agencies.

articles.title: Energy Shortages Hinder DPRK Agriculture's Drought Resilience
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: The Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK) has a notably lower agricultural drought resistance than the ROK. This disparity raises questions about the capacity of the DPRK's agricultural systems to withstand adverse climatic events and sustain food production. One of the primary culprits behind this disparity is the energy shortages that plague the DPRK. The isolationist policies and restrictions imposed by international sanctions complicate the development of robust agricultural systems.

articles.title: Day for the beach
articles.author: Steve Hepburn
articles.summary: Temperatures in Dunedin reached 25.8°C on Saturday. A big crowd was at St Kilda Beach and other beaches reported good numbers. The warm temperatures were caused by westerly winds coming down from high ground and losing their moisture. Showers came in last night and more showers are likely today.

articles.title: NOAA issues La Niña Advisory
articles.author: Aaron Colby
articles.summary: La Niña has returned and is expected to remain active this winter. La Niña is a part of a cycle known as the El Niño Southern Oscillation. It is determined by sea surface temperature trends in the Pacific Ocean along the Equator. It means the overall pattern will be favorable for dry and warm conditions.

articles.title: Warning to not set thermostat above this temperature
articles.author: Rebecca Carey
articles.summary: The optimum room temperature for bedrooms is around 18°C and 21°C for living rooms. Dr Neel Patel has warned Brits not to turn up the central heating above these temperatures as it can exacerbate seven health conditions including asthma, migraines, allergies and nosebleeds.

articles.title: Warning to Brits to not set thermostat above this temperature as winter approaches
articles.author: Rebecca Carey
articles.summary: There's an optimum temperature for your house and the ideal conditions differ between your bedroom and living space. The optimum room temperature for bedrooms is around 18°C and for the living room it's around 21°C. Dr Neel Patel, a GP has warned Brits not to turn up the central heating above these temperatures as it's bad for their health.

articles.title: History of World War II: The Soviet Red Army's Winter Campaign 80 Years Ago
articles.author: Shane Quinn
articles.summary: The winter of 1941-42 was one of the coldest on record in Russia. The Wehrmacht inflicted 620,000 casualties on the Red Army during the three months of January to March 1942. General Georgy Zhukov, the Soviets' top commander, complained that he had so far lost 276,000 soldiers in the winter fighting, and received only 100,000 reinforcements.

articles.title: Australia Palestinians Gaza
articles.author: 민주네 리서치
articles.summary: People wave flags and hold placards during a rally in Sydney, Australia, supporting Palestinians in Gaza on Sunday, Oct. 12, 2025, supporting Palestine in Gaza. (AP Photo/Rick Rycroft) People wave flags, hold placard and wave placards at rally.

articles.title: Tropics Watch: Atlantic calm sparks hope amid warm Caribbean waters
articles.author: Daniel McFarland
articles.summary: The Atlantic tropics are quieting down amid the waning days of the hurricane season. There are no immediate tropical threats looming for the U.S. coastline. Long-range outlook urges vigilance over the Caribbean Sea, where sea surface temperatures remain anomalously warm.

articles.title: Horry County coastal flood advisory in place through Sunday afternoon
articles.author: Adam Benson
articles.summary: Flood advisory is in place for Horry County until 12:30 p.m. Sunday. Coastal flooding is still possible today across the lower portions of the coastal areas. Flash flood warnings have been issued for Georgetown. New precipitation amounts between a half and three-quarters of an inch are possible.

articles.title: Food security blow as Kenya hunger levels at 25-year high
articles.author: Nation Media Group
articles.summary: The number of Kenyans lacking sufficient food has increased by 14.6 percentage points in less than a decade. The 2025 Global Hunger Index reports that 36.8 percent of people in Kenya are undernourished. This is a sharp increase from 22.2 percent in 2016 and raises concerns about the country's progress toward food security. The report attributes this setback to prolonged droughts, high food prices, and declining household purchasing power. Arid and semi-arid areas account for almost 70 percent of those facing food insecurity. Conflict and instability in neighbouring countries have worsened food security in Kenya.

articles.title: Researchers issue warning on overlooked threat that could cause economic crisis: 'Uncertainties for the future are rising sharply'
articles.author: Laurelle Stelle
articles.summary: The Technical University of Munich has published a study on the economic impact of climate change on Europe's forests. Southern Europe will suffer economic losses regardless of how much the temperature rises. Most predicted scenarios involve extensive damage. Northern Europe, including Scandinavia, is the only region that may get through relatively unscathed.

articles.title: WEATHER (6:00 AM, Oct 12): Cloudiness, scattered showers today; increase in Saharan dust this weekend
articles.summary: A pulse of moisture moving westward is expected to result in occasional cloudiness with scattered showers across the area during today. There will be a slight increase in Saharan dust concentration. Individuals with respiratory sensitivities are advised to take necessary precautions. Seas are expected to be slight to moderate with wave heights near 3 ft along the west coast and up to 7 ft along east coast.

articles.title: Blocking Hurricanes, Will He Deport Them too? How Vast is a President's Meteorological Might?
articles.author: Tom Madden
articles.summary: There has been no hurricane landfall in the U.S. this hurricane season. President Trump's tough stance on immigration, National Guard troops and the border with Mexico has scared away hurricanes. FEMA funding has been cut and the agency has fewer staff and resources to deal with disasters.

articles.title: Climate-curious but confused? Grab a beer and some cards.
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: by | | Climate Change is a website dedicated to the study of climate change. For more information, visit: http://www.climatalkin.org/news/environment/environmental-change/chimatockexchange.html.

articles.title: When do the clocks go back? Exact time and date to make the change
articles.author: Anuska Banerjee
articles.summary: The clocks will go back at 2am on Sunday, October 26, marking the official start of Greenwich Mean Time. Most smartphones and digital devices will update automatically, but analogue clocks and digital clocks such as those in cars and ovens will need to be changed manually. The tradition of changing the clocks began more than 100 years ago when parliament passed the Summer Time Act in 1916, creating British Summer Time.

articles.title: Fritz Wetherbee: Grumpy Old Men Road
articles.author: Fritz Wetherbee
articles.summary: Just east of the Shelburne Birches is Grumpy Old Men Road. Fritz will tell you the story there. See the video archive of Fritz's stories here.    .   for more information about Fritz and his stories. For more information, visit Fritz's website.

articles.title: Widespread rain and wind continues
articles.author: Krista Chang
articles.summary: Flash flood warnings have been issued for Horry and Georgetown counties. Coastal flooding is still possible today across the lower portions of the coastal areas. Sunday is another gusty day with winds reaching up to 30 mph. Monday morning we will still see some moisture across the coast and a chance for lingering rain.

articles.title: Experts warn of rising mental health crisis linked to climate change
articles.author: Phidel Kizito
articles.summary: Climate change is a public health concern in Kenya. Droughts, floods, and rising temperatures are driving up cases of psychological distress, depression, and trauma-related disorders. Low- and middle-income countries are bearing the brunt of these mental health impacts. Rural farmers and pastoralists are disproportionately affected because their livelihoods depend on agriculture and livestock.

articles.title: Gardeners urged to put hot sauce or chilli on bird feeders in October
articles.author: Alex Evans
articles.summary: RSPB share their guide on bird feeders. Gardeners are urged to put Tabasco or hot sauce on their bird feeder as soon as they can this October to help feed hungry birds that need food in autumn. Thanks to a huge reduction in insect populations, birds have far less to eat than they used to.

articles.title: Herald saves us with exclusive climate ‘breakthrough'
articles.summary: A 17-year-old has disproved the math behind climate change. The only source tying this to climate science is a Herald letter from Oct. 5. Jim Sims is grateful to the Herald for providing unbiased reporting from trusted sources.

articles.title: La Niña is here. What incoming polar winds mean for Oklahoma's 2025 winter weather
articles.author: Josh Kelly
articles.summary: La Niña is making its way from the Pacific Ocean and is heading to Oklahoma for a cold winter. La Niña changes the jet stream, which can make for very different winters across North America. In Oklahoma, this will manifest most in a drier and warmer winter than on average, but still cold.

articles.title: Orangeville's Oct. 12 forecast: Mainly cloudy
articles.author: Torstar Open Data Team
articles.summary: This story was automatically generated using data from Environment and Climate Change Canada and has been automatically shared via Twitter, Facebook and other social media channels.    .      i   in this case, the article link has been copied and saved.

articles.title: Environmentalist Point to Normal October Nor'Easter as Cause for Panic About Climate Change
articles.author: Shore News Network
articles.summary: Nor'easter is expected to bring heavy rain, coastal flooding and damaging winds to New Jersey. Environmentalists are calling on Governor Phil Murphy to adopt NJPACT Coastal Rules to protect the state's vulnerable shoreline communities from worsening climate impacts. NJPact is a series of environmental regulatory reforms in New Jersey designed to address climate change by reducing emissions and adapting to sea-level rise and extreme weather.

articles.title: What Trump calls a ‘con job' is a real climate crisis that we ignore only at great peril
articles.author: Mark Gongloff
articles.summary: Zeke Hausfather, a climate scientist at Berkeley Earth, has produced a chart showing how fast the planet is heating up as a result of the greenhouse gases that humans pump into the atmosphere. The past 100 years have been the hottest in recorded human history, according to Andrew Dessler, a scientist at Texas A&M University.

articles.title: Türkiye's major cities could face water shortages by 2050
articles.author: Daily Sabah With Aa
articles.summary: Some Turkish cities could face severe water shortages in the coming decades if climate change continues unchecked. Pusan University in South Korea, Adana and Mersin may experience 'Day Zero Drought' by 2030, while Istanbul and Diyarbakır could face it by 2050.

articles.title: Women in Ghana fight to sustain oyster farming tradition
articles.author: Naa Adorkor Cudjoe
articles.summary: Beatrice Nutekpor weaves through the mangroves in Tsokomey community, just outside Ghana's capital of Accra, every day to harvest oysters for sale. It's a family tradition she's been doing since she was 15. The Development Action Association nonprofit lost its U.S. aid as a result of Donald Trump's decision to cut foreign aid contracts.

articles.title: Humans caused climate crisis, and they can stop it
articles.summary: Nimalan Venkatesan is in 10th grade at Glacier Peak High School in Snohomish. Global warming is caused by human activities like burning fossil fuels and cutting down forests. Switching to renewable energy and conserving trees can help slow down the rise in temperature.

articles.title: Sydney records warmest night in seven months with 28 degrees Celsius at midnight on Thursday
articles.author: Global Desk
articles.summary: Sydney recorded its warmest night in seven months on Thursday morning, October 9, with temperatures reaching 27.7 degrees Celsius at midnight. High cloud over eastern New South Wales exacerbated the overnight warmth by trapping heat near the surface and preventing it from radiating into space. Sydney's lowest temperature at 6:45 a.m. Thursday was 22.2 degrees Celsius.

articles.title: The high cost of climate change
articles.author: Frans Camilleri
articles.summary: There has been a marked 83% increase in recorded climate disasters over the past five decades. Approximately 1.6 billion people were directly affected by these events in the decade from 2014 to 2023. Malta's mean annual ambient temperature has risen by around 1.5 o C on average over the last few decades. Over the last 50 years, rainfall decreased by more than 10 mm compared to the climate average. 60% of the twenty warmest sea temperatures have occurred during the last 20 years, and there has been an average decadal increase of half a degree in the mean sea temperature. Malta faces the threat of a sea level rise.

articles.title: In just a day, volunteers found hundreds of birds that crashed into GTA buildings
articles.author: Olivia Piercey
articles.summary: More than 300 birds crashed into windows across the Greater Toronto Area last Wednesday. Michael Mesure, executive director of Fatal Light Awareness Program (FLAP), found 20 birds around just one building in Markham on Wednesday. In the last month, about 2,000 birds died from collisions with buildings around the GTA. Most killer culprits are buildings under 20 metres tall with windows reflecting nearby trees, bushes or grassland. North American bird populations have dropped by billions in 50 years.

articles.title: Bajali DC Mridul Kumar Das launches special climate change classes in schools
articles.author: Sentinel Digital Desk
articles.summary: The District Commissioner of Bajali introduced special classes on climate change in all Higher Secondary Schools across the district. Mridul Kumar Das, ACS, conducted the first session today. He explained the causes and consequences of climate change and discussed practical steps that individuals can take to monitor and reduce its impact.

articles.title: Sydney records warmest night in seven months with 28 degrees Celsius at midnight on Thursday
articles.author: The Economic Times
articles.summary: Sydney experienced its warmest night in seven months on Thursday, October 9, with temperatures reaching 30 degrees.       on the night of October 9th, Sydney experienced the warmest temperature in 7 months. It was 30 degrees on that night.

articles.title: Antarctic Sea Ice Is Melting Faster Than Ever And It Could Unleash A Hidden Carbon ...
articles.author: Zeenews
articles.summary: A new study reveals that melting Antarctic sea ice could release massive amounts of trapped carbon dioxide. This could speed up global warming, according to the study. The study was published in the journal "The International Journal of Climatology". It says that this could be a good thing for the environment.

articles.title: New Global World Heritage Review Reveals Great Barrier Reef Still On Critical List, As Ningaloo And Shark Bay Under ‘significant Concern'
articles.author: The National Tribune
articles.summary: IUCN has again rated the Great Barrier Reef's outlook as 'critical' in its new World Heritage Outlook report released last night at the IUCN World Conservation Congress in Abu Dhabi. The conservation status of Nyinggulu/Ningaloo Reef and Shark Bay has been downgraded to 'significant concern' due to climate change. The Albanese government's emissions reduction target of 62-70% by 2035 is on track with global warming of over 2°C.

articles.title: Experts issue warning that beloved pantry staples may soon get pricier: 'There's real danger'
articles.author: Katie Lowe
articles.summary: Experts issue warning that beloved pantry staples may soon get pricier: 'There's real danger' Scotland's food and drink industry faces a growing, expensive threat that experts are calling "climateflation". Rising global temperatures and unstable weather are driving up grocery bills. Some of Scotland's most iconic, heritage products — from scotch and seafood to summer strawberries — are at risk. The James Hutton Institute is developing climate-resilient barley strains.

articles.title: Thread by @ziophobes on Thread Reader App
articles.summary: Ziophobe of the Day is exposing the Ziophobes of the Clown Flotilla. Greta Tintin Thunberg is an autistic girl, mostly known for climate activism. She's now travelling to Israel almost every month on diesel-chugging, highly polluting vessels, throwing polluting cellphones and plastic into the ocean. She has no grasp of the nature of Hamas and the reality of the conflict.

articles.title: Hong Kong can expect fewer but stronger typhoons in the future: expert
articles.author: Harvey Kong
articles.summary: Leung Wing-mo warns of fewer but stronger typhoons in the future due to climate change. He urges the use of wooden panels and additional breakwaters instead of tape to protect property. The Western Pacific and South China Sea may get about 30 tropical cyclones on average per year, but the proportion of strong typhoons will increase.

articles.title: The Ross's Goose spotted at Marshside RSPB Reserve
articles.author: Jack Stott
articles.summary: The Ross's Goose was spotted at the Marshside RSPB Reserve, in Southport on October 6. The bird usually breeds in the High Arctic and winters in the Southern United States and Mexico. October is an amazing time for birding in Lancashire with tens of thousands of Pink-footed Geese flying in from Iceland.

articles.title: Panama City plants Oak Tree as Symbol of Resilience 7 years after Hurricane Michael
articles.author: Mae Harper
articles.summary: Panama City officials dedicated a new Southern oak tree named 'New Sentry' at Oaks by the Bay Park on Friday. It's been seven years since Hurricane Michael devastated the Panhandle. The tree planting ceremony was held in partnership with the Community Redevelopment Agency.

articles.title: 'Tip of the iceberg': record human trafficking reports
articles.summary: Human trafficking reports in Australia have soared to a record high. People are aware of the signs and warning the police about the problem. The number of human trafficking cases is on the rise in Australia.   in the last year has risen by 30 per cent.

articles.title: 'Tip of the iceberg': record human trafficking reports
articles.author: Callum Godde
articles.summary: Forced removal and modern slavery reports have doubled in Australia. Human trafficking alerts are at an all-time high in the country. Forced removal, modern slavery and human trafficking alerts have doubled since 2010. For confidential support call the Samaritans in Australia on 08457 90 90 90, visit a local Samaritans branch or click here.

articles.title: Japan summers lengthened by 3 weeks over 42 yrs: researchers
articles.author: Mainichi Japan
articles.summary: Japanese summers have lengthened by about three weeks over the 42 years from 1982 to 2023. The rise in sea surface temperatures due to global warming is the main factor. In 1982, the summer period lasted 92 days, from June 29 to Sept. 28, but by 2023 it had grown to 121 days, running from June 11 to October 9.

articles.title: NIGERIA'S LOOMING FOOD INSECURITY
articles.author: Nigeria
articles.summary: Nigeria is slipping into a food crisis that threatens its economic stability and the survival of millions of its citizens. The main drivers of this looming crisis are insecurity, banditry, kidnapping, and clashes between farmers and herders. Poor road networks mean that farmers who produce crops struggle to transport them to urban markets. Post-harvest losses account for up to 40% of total production due to lack of storage facilities and processing industries.

articles.title: New global World Heritage review reveals Great Barrier Reef still on the critical list, as Ningaloo and Shark Bay under ‘significant concern' - Australian Marine Conservation Society
articles.author: Amy Gould
articles.summary: IUCN has again rated the conservation status of the Great Barrier Reef as critical, the worst status available. The conservation outlook has worsened for four of Australia's Natural World Heritage properties, including Ningaloo Reef and Shark Bay. The Australian Marine Conservation Society (AMCS) has warned that the Federal and Queensland governments are falling short on their duty to protect the reef.

articles.title: Double red-flag issued along Volusia coast due to hazardous conditions
articles.author: FOX 35 Digital Staff
articles.summary: Beach safety officials have issued double red flags along the Volusia County coastline due to hazardous conditions and rip currents. Seaweed has washed ashore, but it shouldn't be disturbed. Beach driving access will likely remain limited over the next several days until conditions improve.

articles.title: Experts issue warning about risky schemes to combat powerful natural phenomenon: 'Just Band-Aids'
articles.author: Gabriel Holton
articles.summary: Experts issue warning about risky schemes to combat powerful natural phenomenon: 'Just Band-Aids'. Arctic is warming nearly four times faster than the global average. Redirecting funding into pollution cuts and resilient infrastructure will protect polar ice and the communities that depend on it.

articles.title: Climate disasters costing us billions of dollars annually: minister
articles.author: Jamila Achakzai
articles.summary: Pakistan is among the world's most climate-vulnerable nations despite contributing less than one per cent of global greenhouse gas emissions. Monsoon flooding has caused over 950 deaths, displaced millions and submerged over 4,500 villages in Punjab alone. The 2022 Pakistan floods affected over 33 million people, destroyed or damaged 2.3 million houses, caused over 1,700 deaths and inflicted $30 billion in damages to infrastructure, housing, agriculture and the economy.

articles.title: Wildland Fire Preparedness level raises to Level 3 due to conditions
articles.author: Dailyn Wells
articles.summary: The Texas A&M Forest Service has raised the Wildland fire preparedness level to level 3 due to current and expected wildfire activity across the state. Officials will continue to monitor the situation and remain ready to respond to any requests for assistance. For the latest Amarillo news and regional updates, check with MyHighPlains.com and tune in to KAMR Local 4 News at 5, 6, and 10 p.m. and Fox 14 News at 9:00 pm CST.

articles.title: Japan summers lengthened by 3 weeks over 42 yrs: researchers
articles.author: Kyodo
articles.summary: Japanese summers have lengthened by about three weeks over the 42 years from 1982 to 2023. The number of days classified as summer has increased each year, while the length of winter has remained relatively the same. The trend toward longer summers and winters will intensify if warming continues.

articles.title: The high cost of climate change
articles.author: The Malta Independent
articles.summary: As global temperatures climb, weather systems are changing. Extreme weather events that may have hit just once in our grandparents' lifetimes are becoming more common in ours. There has been a rise in the number of droughts, hurricanes, floods, and heat waves.

articles.title: Can South Carolina's sewage systems adapt to a changing climate?
articles.author: The Post
articles.summary: There's a growing population and rising tides putting pressure on South Carolina's sewage systems. Can the utilities adapt fast enough to protect the state's rivers, streams and estuaries from pollution? The state's utilities are concerned about their ability to cope with the situation.

articles.title: Luxon "Goes Full Trump" With Climate-denying Methane Backdown
articles.author: Scoop
articles.summary: At the heart of the move to reduce methane targets is a controversial accounting trick called "no additional warming". This trick is designed to justify continued high levels of agricultural methane emissions even though science shows they must fall fast.      Â
